This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from

http://www.hylid.clara.co.uk/caer.htm

Ive also got a ~400 piece puzzle from fragments of the small bones that run along the tail.

>>4353337
Giga was a pack-hunting animal that didn't reach full skeletal maturity until its 40s and then probably lived another decade and a half.
Rex was very likely a solitary predator that lived fast and died young.
But in the end, the victor in a one-on-one fight between a 40-year-old Giga and a 25-year-old Rex would be whoever landed the first blow. Part of me wants to say the Giga because it's older and has more experience, but the other part of me wants to say the Rex because it mostly hunted animals that were the same size as it.

>>4355660
>The Ojo Alamo formation
That's a Maastrichtian-era fossil site. The Carchaodontosaurs didn't survive the Cenomanian-Turonian boundary event. Tyrannosaurs never made it to Africa or South America where the Carchs achieved their most massive sizes and they went extinct at roughly the same time the North American and Asian Carchs also went extinct during the Cenomanian-Turonian boundary event. So you can't really point to Tyrannosaurs as displacing the Carchs.
The Titanosaurs that the Carchs hunted took a substantial hit during the extinction but eventually managed to bounce back. For whatever reason, the Carchs were (probably) unable to survive the hardship, and the niche of Sauropod hunter remained unfilled. Though the Abelisaurs in South America and Africa and Megaraptoran in South America and Australia were getting larger so one of those groups probably would have filled that niche eventually had the K-PG event not happened.

>>4355446
Another related but less obvious reason relates to ontogeny and osteal histology

a croc is born 1/10th of adult size or less and will grow throughout its entire life, often for decades

a bird is born 1/3 adult size and will reach full size in a few weeks and never grow again

because of these differences in development the bones are significantly different at hatching in birds. E.g. the skull is almost adult size at birth because once those bones fuse they stop growing. The chest and hips are overdeveloped because breathing is much more important to birds than crocs. Birds have to basically go from embryo to adult in a couple weeks while crocs don't really change in much of anything but size over periods of years and decades.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4353674
Actually this has got me thinking about predator/prey strategies.

A predator needs to hunt in order to eat, while an herbivore only needs to graze grass.
When in a fight the risk/reward calculation is different for each. A herbivore can be badly wounded in a fight, yet still feed itself by eating grass. A predator that's wounded will be unable to hunt, and will starve to death.
This is why herbivores are much more aggressive and much more likely to attack a human for no good reason. They simply have less to lose from the encounter.

This simple logic simply doesn't work on mustelid though. They will fight aggressively even if it kills them. It's a completely different type of survival strategy. Just thought this was an interesting observation, that's all.

You can, if they're "real" ghost shrimp, paleomontenes sp., they're unlikely to have any sort of issues. If there's any Macrobrachium sp. in there, they'll prey on cherries, but also on the "real" ghosts, so you'll know before you add cherries if there will be an issue.

Keep an eye out for any ghosts that grow bigger or turn brown instead of just getting mottled stripes. Those may not be good community residents.
